Why Bluesky Will Probably Never Be It | cmdr-nova@internet:~$
Why Bluesky Will Probably Never Be It

Author: @cmdr_nova@mkultra.monster

Published: 16 Jul 2024


This is going to be a sort of long one (or maybe it won‚Äôt?), because I have a lot of thoughts as a tech and social media enthusiast, and some of those thoughts have to do with how I feel about the direction that social media is moving in. How I feel about Mastodon, and Nostr, side-by-side, and what the biggest problems with Bluesky are.

So, let‚Äôs jump right the heck in ‚Ä¶

Nostr, the misconceptions, and the truth

I recently wrote about Nostr, and its relayed protocol of user-owned identity that you can take ‚Ä¶ wherever. I outlined a lot of thoughts and impressions I initially had, and then what I wrote went to Reddit, and then it found itself on Nostr. It got there entirely outside my own involvement. I posted to Mastodon, and almost nowhere else.

This inspired me to log back in, and set some things up (such as domain verification from one of a few domains I own), and then I explored a bit. I interacted with people, participated in some community events that came up spontaneously, and really dug into the extreme multitude of features that run across the Nostr network.

Let‚Äôs just say, I was pretty floored, and some of the impressions I had were wrong. Such as thinking that a place that is more centered around the idea of lacking censorship, or robust moderation, must be filled with toxic, horrible trolls. In the couple of days I‚Äôve been messing with the network, I think I‚Äôve muted like one person who said some off-the-wall shit in my notifications.

But ‚Ä¶ I think Nostr has nasty people just in the same way Twitter, Threads, and Mastodon do. They exist, and they always will, no matter where you go.

Suffice to say, I learned a lot about what decentralization was, and now is. I was given an article by user @7fqx@ditto.pub that gave some really in-depth information about the emergence of decentralization‚ÄìScuttlebutt, ActivityPub, and then ATProtocol, and Nostr.

I‚Äôm not going to lie, I originally started writing this as a hit piece against Bluesky, thinking their ATProtocol was just a riff of what Nostr was doing. But, apparently, both ATP and Nostr were developed independent of each other, and mostly without any knowledge of one or the other. I think that‚Äôs ‚Ä¶ actually pretty wild, and strange.

On the topic of decentralization, which is something I feel is integral to the future of the internet, I now understand Mastodon to be a place of islands, and decentralization that occurs in a way that‚Äôs more like isolated communities talking to other isolated communities. Like the latter half of The Walking Dead.

In a way, it‚Äôs decentralization, the half-measure. The full-measure, that comes with some iffy trade-offs some may not like, is Nostr, and ATProtocol.

You take your identity, your thoughts, your posts, and you move freely between pieces of software, and networks, and you lose nothing (this is nearly the direct opposite of Mastodon, where moving to a new server means burning everything you‚Äôve ever posted, to the ground). And, honestly, I‚Äôm kind of starting to feel like that‚Äôs how it should be. The downside, is that, on Nostr, you have a public key, and a secret key. Your secret key is something you use to log in and sign events coming from your account, and your public key is basically your identity. That‚Äôs not the iffy part, though. The iffy part, is that people can use your public key to see all of your data except direct messages (which are encrypted).

Not entirely too scary, unless you‚Äôre doing a lot of weird things on your account. But definitely something you should know if you decide that this is a journey you want to take, and you‚Äôre not jaded from hearing about how much Jack Dorsey loved Nostr and it‚Äôs Bitcoin affiliation (a lot of people across different platforms hold a lot of dislike for the man).

At this point, I‚Äôm less worried about the power consumption of BTC transactions, and have more shifted that focus to content farms from the likes of Microsoft and Nvidia buying up all the AI tech they can get their grubby little hands on.

That aside, I‚Äôm not writing this to blow smoke up the Bluesky developer‚Äôs butts. I, in fact, am not favorable of Bluesky and there are some specific reasons for that. Maybe this spells their downfall, or maybe they‚Äôll be a tight-knit community that doesn‚Äôt really expand all that much, forever.

Bluesky, the Apple of social media

Bluesky is a place that a couple million people call home (I think, last I saw, it was around 6 million or so). There‚Äôs no algorithm, and much like Nostr, you own your identity. Except, for now, that‚Äôs mostly tied to the website‚Äôs central server.

Now, obviously, there are far less people populating Nostr, but Nostr and its relays are able, and are connected to both ActivityPub and Bluesky (just, not through ATProtocol).

Most of what you‚Äôll see on bsky.app are quite a few furries, an actually impressive population of Second Life users, and quite a lot of LGBTQ+ people. None of these things or communities are inherently bad. In fact, I think they‚Äôre probably the only reason Bluesky is really alive at all, today.

My angst and negative feelings about the direction of Bluesky have nothing to do with the LGBTQ+ community, or any other community residing on the platform.

The issues I mainly hold have to do with how far up their own asses the board and developers are, in regard to the platform, and its development over the past year or so. This is why I kind of think of them as the Apple of social media. And you might think, ‚ÄúHey, don‚Äôt you own like a billion pieces of Apple tech?‚Äù

Yeah, I do.

But this is more like if Apple skipped over having Steve Jobs and just went straight to some random guy who didn‚Äôt know what he was doing. You know, like putting up a wall and locking out all potential users for a year, and keeping all new sign-ups under lock and key via exclusive codes. As you might imagine, having that walled-garden erected through six or seven different events where people were leaving Twitter in droves, very likely probably worked against the social network‚Äôs best interest.

Mainly, because Threads came out of absolutely nowhere, and sucked up most of those users.

That‚Äôs only half of the issue, though. The other part to all of this, is that the developers I see directly on Bluesky do not recognize or acknowledge this at all. Paul Frazee, whose influence goes back quite a bit further than Bluesky, posts as though it‚Äôs the greatest platform ever made (maybe just because he‚Äôs a developer for Bluesky). But the website, despite its six million some-odd users, feels almost completely dead.

Which is ridiculous, because, as I‚Äôve said, Nostr has far less users than that, and it most definitely doesn‚Äôt feel dead when you post.

Not to mention, we‚Äôre over a year into Bluesky, and it still, more or less, is propped up to look, feel, and act just like Twitter did in 2014. ATProtocol, in this respect, still feels mostly like an afterthought that‚Äôs inaccessible to most users.

Meanwhile, if you really like Nostr, you can get going with your own chunk of the network immediately, with about a page of install commands.

It‚Äôs this mixture of grandiosity that emanates from Bluesky, and the blunder of keeping their doors closed through one exodus after another, that I think they‚Äôve shot themselves in the feet so much that they now don‚Äôt have feet. They have stumps.

But, if you‚Äôve followed me all the way through this article, I think there‚Äôs a way they can blow the doors open. But, then they‚Äôd have to sort of abandon their idea of the ATProtocol, and stop trying to be the center of social media they most definitely are not, and probably never will be. And, really, that‚Äôs the final issue I have with Bluesky and the ATProtocol.

It feels like they‚Äôre trying to do Nostr, but be corporate-owned. Bluesky doesn‚Äôt feel like it‚Äôs owned by the people, developed by the people, and run by the people. It feels like it‚Äôs run by some suits, who give the impression that the people will have their freedom, as long as they say it‚Äôs okay.

And that, my buddy ol‚Äô pal, just ain‚Äôt okay.

The elephant and the ostrich

Which brings us squarely back to Mastodon, and Nostr. Both platforms have their own merits. Nostr is about controlling your own content, and what you see, and largely eschews censorship to a high degree. But everyone can see almost everything you do and are talking about, whenever they want. Mastodon, on the other hand, puts the tools into a user‚Äôs hands to create a network, and build their own communities, while picking and choosing who those communities interact with. A network that ‚Ä¶ encourages users to police everyone around them ‚Ä¶ which is how we end up with tyrannical admins acting like they work in a prison, and they‚Äôve just been promoted to Warden.

If only there were some way to take the best parts of both of these animals, and make them one.

An elephrich.

For now, though, I am at least pretty content to screw around with both while I feel around and see what sticks. In the age of corporate control and censorship so heavy that people can‚Äôt even say ‚Äúkill‚Äù or ‚Äúsuicide‚Äù any more (these are only two of the most egregious examples I can think of), I think it‚Äôs healthy to explore your options, and cement your identity, and who you are online, before everything else we‚Äôve come to know is lost completely.

If that‚Äôs something you care about, at least.
